importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Publication year of the first memoir, 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki', which became a bestseller in South Korea.
Year the memoir was translated into English, leading to international popularity and inclusion on the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and a New York Times recommendation.
Publication year of the second memoir, 'I Want to Die but I Still Want to Eat Tteokbokki', which addressed ongoing struggles with dysthymia.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2018 to 2025 marks the rise and global impact of Baek Se-hee’s memoirs, especially through mental health advocacy and cross-cultural influence.

keyTakeAways: Baek Se-hee, a South Korean author, wrote a bestselling memoir that openly discussed her struggles with depression and the complex emotional balance between wanting to die and enjoying life’s small pleasures.

Her book, 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki', became a cultural phenomenon in South Korea and gained international acclaim after being translated into English in 2022, reaching major global bestseller lists.
The memoir addressed mental health issues such as dysthymia and therapy, helping reduce stigma around mental illness and encouraging open conversations about emotional well-being.
Baek Se-hee donated her organs—heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys—after her death, saving the lives of five people, demonstrating a life of selflessness and impact beyond her writing.
She was born in 1990, studied creative writing, and worked in publishing before undergoing therapy, which inspired her writing journey and public mental health discourse.

summaryOfNewsArticle: South Korean author Baek Se-hee, known for her deeply personal and candid memoirs about living with depression and dysthymia, has died at age 35. Her book 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki' became a bestseller in South Korea and gained international fame after translation in 2022, reaching major global bestseller lists and receiving recognition from the New York Times. She wrote a follow-up memoir exploring her continued struggles with mental health. Born in 1990 and trained in creative writing, she worked in publishing before beginning therapy, which inspired her writing. Baek donated her heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys, saving five lives. Her legacy includes breaking down mental health stigma through honest storytelling, and her work continues to inspire readers worldwide to confront emotional pain and find hope in small pleasures.
title: Baek Se-hee, author of bestselling memoir 'I Want To Die But I Want To Eat Tteokbokki,' dead at 35
